snippet: Punishments meted out in family court are typically far less harsh than those in criminal court, and defendants are not named.
abstract: Seven football players, who range in age from 15 to 17, accused of hazing and sexual abuse at Sayreville War Memorial High School in New Jersey will be tried as juveniles; punishments meted out in family court are typically far less harsh and because juvenile records are not made public, defendants are not named, shielding them from much of publicity surrounding such a prominent case.
lead_paragraph: Punishments meted out in family court are typically far less harsh than those in criminal court, and defendants are not named.

headline.main: Players in Sayreville Football Hazing and Abuse Case Will Be Tried as Juveniles, Lawyers Say
headline.print_headline: 7 Sayreville Athletes to Be Tried as Juveniles

keywords.value: Sayreville War Memorial High School (Sayreville, NJ)
keywords.name: organizations
